pros: Great place to start, especially if you're in recovery. Support is there, and approaching management and HR with a good attitude proved helpful many times.
cons: A little understaffed at times, turnover can be rough but they're working on it.

review_title: YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED-- THE WORST COMPANY ON THE PLANET!!
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Happy Valley, OR
pros: NO PROS at all. THIS PLACE IS HORRENDOUS. They pay is terrible and debasing and the organization is facilitated by imbeciles. Kim, the supervisor at Happy Valley, is one of the worst. If you need a day off for any reason, they demand that you find coverage for your shift. Irrespective of the reason, they'll find excuses to dock your pay. I am quitting instantly as the morale is on life support and the entire system is hopeless. If you want to work for pennies on the dollar, here is your opportunity. As well, they lie through their teeth about opportunities. Choice is yours!
cons: Everything I already indicated above.

job_title: Drug and Alcohol Technician in Gresham, OR
pros: Overtime, lax attendance requirements make getting lots of overtime easy. Good place to start a career in substance used treatment
cons: Lack of training, poor culture.

pros: Bonuses, Benefits, Kind Supervisors, understanding and respectful
cons: The pay isn’t the best

job_title: Drug and Alcohol Technician in Portland, OR
pros: Lots of opportunity for growth
cons:
Residential sites lack communication
Pay rate is pretty low
Long hours

pros: Generous benefits package. Skill development opportunity.
cons: Incentivised (through weekly bonuses) the providing of clinical service hours .

review_title: Low pay, hard work, terrible benefits
pros: The pro is that you have a job to just get by.
cons: Low pay, lots of work, disorganized place, no respect from management, strange culture. The management does not understand business.

job_title: Behavioral Health Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: valued experience around substance use disorder, growth opportunity
cons: short staffed, and it is a fast paced environment, not enough time

pros:
The ability to use evidence based materials in creative ways, open minds from clinical staff, we give patients many chances to change and only give up when it becomes a safety issue. Staff is hilarious.
Tons of pto, private office, great dental, great hours for parents with school aged kids, the union has our back. We get free food a lot and free trainings. We get to go on a website and earn free ceus during paid time. 
This work isn’t for everyone. Especially people who have little job experience to compare it to or for people who are not specifically drug and alcohol counselor. If you come from a more by the book and see things in a black and white manner than you won’t like it here.
People who understand addiction on this level realize it is harm reduction, Black and white doesn’t exist in this field and it’s putting out fires more often then some elegant therapy that you see on TV.
This is hard work and the right soul and experience is what is needed. It’s not for everyone.
cons: Medical insurance is too high when you want to add family to it. High turn over rate. Some coworkers are a bit uptight but they usually keep to themselves.

job_title: Behavioral Health Counselor in Portland, OR
pros: Hmm. Can't think of any.
cons:
This was my first job in the field of substance abuse counseling. After providing group therapy coverage for several months, I interviewed for, and was offered the position of behavioral health provider.
I expressed to my supervisor during the interview that I may not be qualified for the position. This did not concern her.
Anyway, I was thrown to the wolves, given no training, given no instruction for how to go about my job. My quality of work was nitpicked and unappreciated by my arrogant, uncaring supervisor.
Basically I had to teach myself how to be a drug counselor because the management is so incompetent, self involved and uncaring that they will not even show you how to do your work.. which is incredibly important and affects addicts' lives.
I quit this job because it was going nowhere, only getting worse as discharge summaries piled up and my responsibilities grew and my caseload increased.
For what? 14 dollars an hour? What a joke. I was so unappreciated by staff and clients alike, when the work was to GET PEOPLE SOBER. On a daily basis I was told to figure it out. Found myself in DANGEROUS and DEADLY situations such as clients threatening me, ONLY to be told by my supervisor, oh we can't discharge him.

review_title: Providing a great service in a tough environment
pros:
The community of care givers, professionals, and patients finding new ways to help sick people get well. Seeing the difference that we made, helping patients find dignity and hope in a very dark place. 
Benefits are great. Compensation is good for non profit. Training and access to experienced mentors is great. Support for licensure is great - you can go as far as you want, so long as you can handle the tough patient population.
cons:
Putting patient well being first is sometimes a tough thing to do from a business perspective - employee needs sometimes have to come second.
Working with the MOST marginalized of our community is HARD WORK - and there’s not much that can make it easier.

review_title: The work with patients is hard, but rewarding.
job_title: Clinical Specialist, MSW in Portland, OR
pros: Helping my community and making a difference with patients is a definite Pro. I get over 5 weeks of PTO and health insurance that is less then $40 per month for me. I have supportive co-workers and a good supervisor. Wages are good (for a non-profit social work job), and training and education are paid for.
cons: It is incredibly hard work and patients don't always appreciate what we're trying to accomplish, As a non-profit, there are financial woes, and social work pay is low - here and everywhere else. (36k after 6 years of college and 2 years of post grad experience, which is actually better than other offers I've had.)

pros: Co-workers at CODA are very smart and dedicated. Mid-level management is excellent. For most part, Directors are too--I've had my moments with one or two people -- but generally find that I am listened to and that in the end, the real goal for just about everyone here is to serve clients in meaningful, professional way. CODA, as far as I know, is only (or one of very few) places that has childcare for patients...and one of the big things is reuniting moms and kids, or getting pregnant women with addiction issues the kind of help they need. That is major, in my book.
cons: There is so much need out there. CODA could add night services and help more people who are not getting services anywhere in our area.

review_title: Erratic CEO Let the Wrong Secret Slip in Meeting.
pros: They had a potluck once a month, they never bought us food themselves, but they would allow us to bring food in ourselves for an hour during the day.
cons:
First of all, in a meeting the (very strange and poor planning) CEO let it slip that every CODA location has a clause in the contract that states they are able to leave a lease with no repercussions if Obamacare ever gets repealed. Seems to indicate a poor future with the company.

They are opening a ritzy location on the coast (which all of the upper management are already vying for) instead of fixing the glaring problems they are already drowning under.

review_title: Great training and education support for an early professional. Wish I could have taken my supervisor with me
job_title: Behavioral Health Counselor I in Portland, OR
pros: They believe in the science behind the work and really stand behind it. I learned way more about my profession in the 3 years working there than I did in 4 years of college, mostly through CODA Academy and my supervisor - I moved, but have stayed in touch.
cons: As a not-for-profit, it's not always possible to provide free services. The work is really difficult, the patients don't always get better. Burn-out and turn over are high.

review_title: Weirdly fractured organization run by intelligent people with a lot of talent
pros: The work CODA does is good and the people there are talented, passionate and hard working. The time off is incredible and they will help you along if they can.
cons: The Portland Administration building is disgusting. They use cut rate cleaners. It's in desperate need of an overhaul. I'm still mystified as to how CODA ended up being so disorganized and fractured. It's hard to get anything done and they keep a lot of traditions and people there that need to be let go so they can move on. Salary is what you expect for a non profit

pros: Facilitating groups and working with the patients.
cons: Management, CEO and deputy director

review_title: Compassionate Care for a Vulnerable Population
pros: Everyone that works at CODA is here because they want to be helping the population they work with. They are dedicated to their work and their peers creating strong teams that support each other and make the environment very enjoyable.
cons: It is a very specific population CODA serves. Without alignment to the treatment methods, it can be difficult to adapt.

pros: As a new clinician I was able to learn a great deal about the greater health care system and about the kind of work I wanted to and who I wanted to do it for.
cons: Over worked, lack of consistency from leadership, large groups, low wages, clearly not client centered, asked to do some unethical things, difficult EHR

pros: My mentor called this work experience, "working in the trenches." I learned so much about people. I practiced client centered concealing--I was eventually fired for that--and learned strong MI skills.
cons: Upper management practice unethical, punitive, bully style, and less than encouraging or supportive supervision. The rules, often illegal, change like the wind. Community partners are allowed to create client interventions.

pros: Gain experience if your absolutely green and want to determine if this is the field for you. Good if no other jobs available.
cons: Lacks support, respect and care for employees. Witnessed some unethical but encouraged practices. Bottom line seems to be their only concern. Extremely low pay for the work with specialized population. High turnover, a major determining factor for good management. Dirty and ugly working environment. Verbally abusive and manipulative management.

pros: Potential to help people. Appreciation from the clients. Runs out of properties that could be renovated to good treatment space but unfortunately are rundown filthy.
cons: Bad leadership. A destructive sociopath is in charge of this place. He doesn’t care about what matters for our clients. Knows they don’t have other options, so he’s OK with maltreatment.

review_title: Administration has no addictions or counseling training, and decides policies without them.
pros: You will get training and experience. The counselors are good people who mean well.
cons: The administration is not competent, the wages are poverty level for a high stress job, and the union is not able to assist you in any way.

pros: Unfortunately I cannot think of any pros concerning CODA. Maybe it would be that my supervisor encouraged us to be creative.
cons:
The pay is terrible.
Upper management is terrible.
They have counselors who are not drug counselors counseling drug addicts.
Work atmosphere is terrible.
Their programs are fragmented to the point where clients get lost in the shuffle.
Very high employee turnover.
Morale is nonexistant.
Employee input is not welcome.

job_title: Relief Site Support in Portland, OR
pros: Good place to self-teach skills, and get out. Apply the experience elsewhere.
cons: Internal communication is disjointed at best. High turnover, employee morale low. Lack of protocol regarding training, and onslaught of responsibility foisted upon new employees leaves them overwhelmed highlighting their underpaid positions.

pros: They will hire you with no experience, build you resume and leave
cons: Everything- but sadly, the fact that you have to endure watching patients being mistreated and even their rights being neglected.  If you try to do something about it within the company, you will be ignored and targeted.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Portland, OR
pros: united team mentality,  very supportive to their employees
cons: lower pay, small budget to work with

pros: Other counselors and our positive interactions with each other.
cons: Administration is not doing enough for staff and does not provide bonuses for staff only Tim gets raises.

pros: the colleagues i worked with were great..the admin no.
cons: long hours,low pay,disrespect by admin

review_title: CHEAPEST UNFAIR ETHICALLY INCORRECT PLACE TO WORK!!!!
pros: Great for resume building, BUT THAT WHERE IT STOPS!
cons:
PAY
site
management
ethics
lack of communication and training
